title: Exploring webfont possibilities
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150420095617im_/http:/typophile.com/files/2492921768_ac31accd5c_4996.jpg)

Downloadable webfonts are not just about replacing Verdana with a fancy freeware font.  
Here is an example where a certain text phrase is automatically replaced with a scalable vector glyph from a downloadable font. The underlying text stays untouched, so indexing and copy&paste work like a charm.

See the full article here: [http://opentype.info/blog/2008/05/14/exploring-webfont-possibilities/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150420095617/http:/opentype.info/blog/2008/05/14/exploring-webfont-possibilities/ "http://opentype.info/blog/2008/05/14/exploring-webfont-possibilities/")

Edit: changed "graphic" to "glyph"
author: Typography.Guru

comments.content: Cool, though I wouldn't use the term 'scalable vector graphic', though, as that's actually a specific technology (SVG) which differs from font embedding.
